description: The Microsoft Technology Associate (MTA) validates building-block technology concepts and helps students explore, discover and pursue successful careers in Information Technology (IT) in an exciting and rewarding way! As the first step in the Microsoft Technology Certification Series, this new, entry-level certification provides students with confidence, credibility, and differentiation while focusing on the knowledge required for the 98-366: MTA Networking Fundamentals Exam.  This exam tests your knowledge about networking basics and the configuration of network settings and also covers the basic hardware one will find as network technicians in the field, terminology one is likely to encounter, and about the OSI model and different internet protocols which are foundational to all of networking. To gain an MTA certification, you must pass only one MTA exam.
name: MTA - Networking Fundamentals - 98-366
subtitle: Networking Fundamentals

episodes.description: MTA validates building-block technology concepts and helps students explore, discover and pursue successful careers in Information Technology (IT) in an exciting and rewarding way! As the first step in the Microsoft Technology Certification Series, this new, entry-level certification provides students with confidence, credibility, and differentiation.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.024
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.024 --> 00:00:09.991
In this segment,
we're gonna talk about the MTA,

3
00:00:09.991 --> 00:00:13.648
the Microsoft Technology Associate
exam number 98366.

4
00:00:13.648 --> 00:00:17.190
That's for your Networking Fundamentals
available from Microsoft.

5
00:00:17.190 --> 00:00:20.170
Now, we're gonna do a little overview for
you so you know what to expect from

6
00:00:20.170 --> 00:00:23.780
the exam, what to expect from our videos,
try to help you get through that, so

7
00:00:23.780 --> 00:00:26.620
that you're ready for
that testing booth when that day comes.

8
00:00:26.620 --> 00:00:28.916
Now Ronnie, you've done some
little research for us here,

9
00:00:28.916 --> 00:00:32.126
and you're gonna show us, walk us through
a little bit of what to expect, correct?

10
00:00:32.126 --> 00:00:32.850
>> Right.

11
00:00:32.850 --> 00:00:34.440
We actually take a look here,

12
00:00:34.440 --> 00:00:37.500
the Microsoft technology associate,
is really designed for

13
00:00:37.500 --> 00:00:41.590
the person that is saying, look,
I think I wanna get into the IT world.

14
00:00:41.590 --> 00:00:44.310
And, one of the fields in the IT
world that you really need to at

15
00:00:44.310 --> 00:00:47.290
least have the fundamentals of
before you go on and try and

16
00:00:47.290 --> 00:00:50.380
master the other skills,
is gonna be networking.

17
00:00:50.380 --> 00:00:54.450
And in this particular series of shows,
we're gonna introduce you to the most

18

common concepts that you need to know,
and you definitely need to have

19

a basic understanding of as you

And so, this is one of these types

21

It doesn't necessarily mean

But what it shows them is that you've

00:01:22.765 --> 00:01:25.835
So, let's go ahead and take a look at
what's normally covered in this exam,

27
00:01:25.835 --> 00:01:28.565
and also what we've covered

28
00:01:28.565 --> 00:01:33.506
So, on my computer, I went ahead and
brought up from Microsoft's site itself,

29
00:01:33.506 --> 00:01:36.932
the official exam objective

30

And so if you go and you do a search

For about $115 US,

that will get you a reservation to

you of course, will have this ability

Make sure you actually get ready for

And, you'll just be scheduling your

38
00:02:07.710 --> 00:02:11.160
Now as I scroll on down, Microsoft

00:02:11.160 --> 00:02:13.780
they like calling them
skills measured instead.

40

And what they mean by that is
that here is the technology.

41
00:02:16.470 --> 00:02:18.318
Here is what you have to understand.

42
00:02:18.318 --> 00:02:21.443
And so the only way that we can measure
this is not by whether or not, yes,

00:02:21.443 --> 00:02:22.931
you know what the objectives are,

00:02:22.931 --> 00:02:25.910

So, the way that they've broken it

And, you can see where it's really between

00:02:33.896 --> 00:02:37.865
And even though we have three areas, there

50
00:02:42.350 --> 00:02:45.810
So, this is the one that we

51

52

Taking a look at the very foundations,

54

56

Beginning with the OSI model, which

58

59

60

So we talk, of course, about the, well,

00:03:22.397 --> 00:03:23.706

62
00:03:23.706 --> 00:03:27.855

64
00:03:32.293 --> 00:03:36.353

65
00:03:36.353 --> 00:03:38.510

66

67
00:03:41.780 --> 00:03:44.770
From that point,

68
00:03:44.770 --> 00:03:48.810
The very fact that you and
I can be able to connect to the Internet,

69
00:03:48.810 --> 00:03:52.870
type in a name in a browser, and then
connect automatically to some machine out

70
00:03:52.870 --> 00:03:56.350
there in the world, well that's

71
00:03:56.350 --> 00:04:00.178
It's important that we understand

72
00:04:00.178 --> 00:04:03.920
And then we move on towards

73
00:04:03.920 --> 00:04:06.630
Now, this is where we put

74

75

78
00:04:18.060 --> 00:04:20.630
We talk about the idea of what

79

80
00:04:23.654 --> 00:04:28.356
And then lastly, we do go over

81

82
00:04:32.363 --> 00:04:35.573
This is the main protocol that's

83
00:04:35.573 --> 00:04:39.860
And so, we do spend a good deal of time

84

85

86
00:04:48.738 --> 00:04:53.380
We do take a look at that, and

87
00:04:53.380 --> 00:04:55.594
Now from that point,
I know you're probably saying, Ronnie,

88
00:04:55.594 --> 00:04:56.667
why did you stop at the bottom?

89
00:04:56.667 --> 00:04:59.655
Because, that's actually where
the foundation comes in for us, and

90
00:04:59.655 --> 00:05:03.000
that's why we started there,
instead, with our series of shows.

91
00:05:03.000 --> 00:05:06.990
Now we also, of course, talked about
the basic hardware that you and

92
00:05:06.990 --> 00:05:10.380
I are gonna find as network

93
00:05:10.380 --> 00:05:14.060
If you end up working for a company,

94

what a switch is, as well, and

95
00:05:17.860 --> 00:05:22.578
even more importantly, the different types

96
00:05:22.578 --> 00:05:24.480
Whether we've talked about fiber optics or

97
00:05:24.480 --> 00:05:27.790
twisted pair cable,
these are by far some of the most

98
00:05:27.790 --> 00:05:32.370
important concepts as far as hardware goes
that we need to have an understanding.

99
00:05:32.370 --> 00:05:36.950
Because if we don't, we will actually use
well, hardware that we're not supposed to.

100
00:05:36.950 --> 00:05:41.260
We will not actually understand the basic
concepts, and why they're so important.

101
00:05:41.260 --> 00:05:42.130
But foundationally,

102
00:05:42.130 --> 00:05:46.650
right, to the building of our networks,
these devices are incredibly important.

103
00:05:46.650 --> 00:05:49.870
From that point as well,
we then covered well,

104
00:05:49.870 --> 00:05:53.670
how everything fits together in

105
00:05:53.670 --> 00:05:55.360
So we build up from the theory.

106
00:05:55.360 --> 00:05:57.660
We take a look at the piece of equipment,
and

107
00:05:57.660 --> 00:06:00.960
now we talk about well,
how do all those things fit together?

108
00:06:00.960 --> 00:06:04.510
And the way that they fit together,

109
00:06:04.510 --> 00:06:05.970
local area networks.

110
00:06:05.970 --> 00:06:09.550
A small network, or even a large network,
that's actually combined together, so

111
00:06:09.550 --> 00:06:12.300
that they can actually use
each other as resources.

112
00:06:12.300 --> 00:06:15.650
And, we also talk about
the technology that connects multiple

113
00:06:15.650 --> 00:06:17.600
local area networks together.

114
00:06:17.600 --> 00:06:18.470
And of course, well,

115
00:06:18.470 --> 00:06:23.080
one of the foundations today is wireless
networking, the ability to compute

116
00:06:23.080 --> 00:06:28.160
while on the go without being tethered

117
00:06:28.160 --> 00:06:31.850
And then, some other different terminology
that you're likely to encounter,

118
00:06:31.850 --> 00:06:35.170
such as Internet, intranet, and extranet.

119
00:06:35.170 --> 00:06:37.442
These are terminologies that
you'll hear all the time.

120
00:06:37.442 --> 00:06:42.134
And throughout the entire series, we
emphasize this because as you enter into,

121
00:06:42.134 --> 00:06:45.308
maybe this is a new career for
you, you gotta get used to

122
00:06:45.308 --> 00:06:49.930
just the basic terminology that

123
00:06:49.930 --> 00:06:53.267
So networking fundamentals is
really a key step for you.

124
00:06:53.267 --> 00:06:56.580
For those of you that are actually
going to to pursue something like

125
00:06:56.580 --> 00:06:58.957

126
00:06:58.957 --> 00:07:01.624
But, you're starting right
here with the Microsoft MTA,

127
00:07:01.624 --> 00:07:03.599
that Microsoft Technology Associate, and

128
00:07:03.599 --> 00:07:06.080
that shows an incredible
serious commitment for you.

129
00:07:06.080 --> 00:07:10.010
That you really wanna get into the IT
field if you haven't been in there before,

130
00:07:10.010 --> 00:07:11.590
so take the time.

131
00:07:11.590 --> 00:07:15.140
Take a look at this series of shows
that we've actually completed here, and

132
00:07:15.140 --> 00:07:18.880
then go ahead and
try your hand at the exam as well.

133
00:07:18.880 --> 00:07:21.919
So make sure you take a few moments,
and as you actually do study,

134
00:07:21.919 --> 00:07:25.404
you actually end up seeing that you may
find there's certain areas that you

135
00:07:25.404 --> 00:07:27.082
actually really are attracted to.

136
00:07:27.082 --> 00:07:30.140
And that will also help guide
your career into the future

137
00:07:30.140 --> 00:07:31.574
>> All right, Ronnie, thank you so

138
00:07:31.574 --> 00:07:34.907
much for that overview for the MTA,
the network fundamentals examination,

139
00:07:34.907 --> 00:07:37.124
the certification that
they have prepared for us.

140
00:07:37.124 --> 00:07:41.086
And hopefully we'll see you
in the upcoming episodes.

141
00:07:41.086 --> 00:07:47.069
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the basics of computer networks utilizing the OSI and TCP/IP reference models. They teach you about the differences between the two models, how they are used to standardize networks, and the layers that comprise them.
episodes.title: OSI Model

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue networking basics by explaining two of the most fundamental protocols used in networks; the Transport Control Protocol (TCP) and the User Datagram Protocol (UDP). They also explain the use of different networking ports and their associated port numbers. All very important to anyone wishing to understand computer networks.
episodes.title: OSI Model Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explain IP addressing which is necessary for connecting devices on a network. They cover all the major bases involved in IP addressing such as the addresses themselves, subnet masks, and gateways; what they are and how they are used to connect devices.
episodes.title: Understanding IPv4

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel continue to explain IP addressing which is necessary for connecting devices on a network. They cover all the major bases involved in IP addressing such as the addresses themselves, subnet masks, and gateways; what they are and how they are used to connect devices.
episodes.title: Understanding IPv4 Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel describe Internet Protocol version 6 or IPv6. They explain how the new version differs from its predecessor as well as ways that they are similar in function. Specific topics covered are the IPv6 address, prefix number, gateway, and backward compatibility with IPv4.
episodes.title: Understanding IPv6

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue explaining the IPv6 address, this time going over some special or reserved IPv6 addresses like the Link Local address, as well as Private, Multicast, and Loopback IPv6 addresses.
episodes.title: Understanding IPv6 Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie cover the topic of Domain Name Resolution or DNS which enables you and I to use human language to interact with computers that rely on numbered addresses for communication. They explain how we use DNS to convert the name of a website to the actual IP address instead of needing to remember a myriad of IP addresses ourselves.
episodes.title: Understanding Name Resolution

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain two of the most widely used networking services, namely the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol(DHCP) and Remote access. They walk you through the process of dynamically assigning IP addresses using DHCP services. Then they show you how to use the different Remote Access methods like Remote Desktop and Remote Assistance, found in the Microsoft operating systems.
episodes.title: Understanding Network Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe some of the different tools and protocols used to help troubleshoot and verify network connectivity. Some of the tools and protocols discussed include: ping, tracert, ipconfig, DNS, telnet, and Netstat.
episodes.title: Understanding TCP/IP

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie dive into the wonderful world of network switches and how they are used to connect attached devices. They talk about all the fundamental basics like transmission speeds, ports, and Virtual Local Area Networks.
episodes.title: Understanding Switches

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel continue detailing the workings of network switches. Here they move into more complex topics like Layer2 and Layer3 switching, security options, switching types or methods, and MAC Table propagation.
episodes.title: Understanding Switches Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore how we are able to connect networks together using network routers. They detail how a router is able to learn about different networks using Dynamic Routing, or how you can set a route manually using Static routes. They also cover the topics of transmission speeds and default routes.
episodes.title: Understanding Routers

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue explaining network routers moving specifically into the topic of Network Address Translation(NAT) which allows multiple devices to share a single internet connection. They then show you how to use Windows Server 2008 R2 as a router for you network.
episodes.title: Understanding Routers Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe the different wired and wireless media types used to connect end devices to a network. They detail the specifics of both copper and fiber cabling including transmission speeds and cable lengths. Then they move into wireless standards and their corresponding speeds, distances, and even security methods.
episodes.title: Understanding Media Types

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Don dissect a common computer network and explore the different elements that allow system to communicate. Don uses Wireshark to demonstrate the difference between regular network traffic and encrypted network traffic. He also shows how using a VPN can be used to encrypt traffic.
episodes.title: Network Infrastructure

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Don explain the difference between external and internal IP addresses and how a user can determine which one he or she is on. Don breaks down how a dial-up modem works as well as DSL. He also explains the difference between the various leased line options available. He finally shows how wireless network speeds stack up against each standard.
episodes.title: Network Infrastructure Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Don compare the various network topologies available. He begins by explaining the legacy type topologies such as physical bus and physical ring. He then moves on to star and hybrid topologies. Don finishes the episode by explaining how collisions work and different methods used to mitigate them.
episodes.title: Network Infrastructure Part 3
